awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Empowering Open Law and Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Research transparency provides immense value across all areas of scholarly inquiry by helping to reveal the rigor, reliability, and relevance of, and to make more evaluable, all types of research.  Scholars who engage in qualitative inquiry sometimes find it difficult to make their work transparent, i.e. to clearly communicate the meticulous and systematic research procedures and practices that they employ to generate and analyze qualitative data, and to clearly portray the evidentiary value of those data. Annotation for Transparent Inquiry (ATI), an emerging approach to increasing the transparency of published qualitative and multi-method social science, helps to address those challenges. This project aims to develop and test a new software tool that will empower scholars to use ATI to reveal the procedures they followed to generate data, explicate the logic of their analysis, and directly link to underlying data such as interviews or archival documents. The tool will thus help researchers and the public to better understand and evaluate qualitative research and provide easier access to the rich data underlying such work. The partnership between researchers, academic data repositories, and creators of open-source software that the project represents should make a significant contribution to infrastructure for research and education. The project also encourages intellectual democratization, enhancing access to transparency practices, to key insights and findings in social science and legal scholarship, and to research data. 

ATI empowers authors to annotate their publications using interoperable web-based annotations that add valuable details about their work’s evidentiary basis and analysis, excerpts from data sources that underlie claims, and potentially links to the data sources themselves. The prototype for a new open-source tool that the project will develop will allow scholars to Restructure, Edit and Package Annotations (Anno-REP).  Anno-REP will empower scholars to create and curate web-based annotations at any point in the writing process; signal their motivation; and publish those annotations on a web page in tandem with the scholarly work that they accompany. These innovations will significantly ease the use of ATI and facilitate and encourage its seamless integration into the writing and publishing processes, promoting scientific progress through qualitative inquiry. The project will solicit feedback for Anno-REP’s continued development from ten scholars with familiarity with ATI, and will also evaluate the tool through a workshop including 20 legal scholars (faculty and graduate students). In order to promote the use and hasten the scholarly adoption of both ATI and Anno-REP, the project will encourage and help scholars to propose work that has been annotated using ATI and Anno-REP for presentation at disciplinary conferences. In addition, it will organize a symposium of articles that use, and analyze the use of, ATI for submission to, review by, and publication in a top legal journal.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Research transparency provides immense value across all areas of scholarly inquiry by helping to reveal the rigor, reliability, and relevance of all types of research. The “Empowering Open Law and Science” project significantly enhanced how qualitative research in law and science and beyond can be made more transparent. The project built on Annotation for Transparent Inquiry (ATI), an approach that supports qualitative inquiry by allowing researchers to annotate key claims and sections in their work and link them to additional explanations and/or primary data. Most significantly, the project developed, tested, improved, and made freely available the open source “Anno-REP” tool that allows researchers to easily create Annotation for Transparent Inquiry projects (https://anno-rep.org). We also worked closely with researchers in law and science to expand our understanding of research transparency and how it is practiced and understood by qualitative researchers. Finally, grounded in these activities, it expanded awareness and use of ATI.

A key obstacle to more transparent research is the burden it places on researchers: every transparency-related task (data sharing, documentation, annotation, etc.) requires more work of researchers seeking to follow best practices. Technology cannot solve this problem, but it can alleviate it. In developing Anno-REP, we followed feedback we had previously received from researchers in designing Anno-REP in a way that lets them work with familiar tools and file formats such as MS Word and PDFs. We conducted an intense initial round of user-testing and improvements of the application and further improved it based on the comments of participants in an in-person workshop who had worked in-depth with the application. The finalized product is easy to use, feature rich, and fully integrated into workflows for ATI at the Qualitative Data Repository: Users can upload a document annotated in Word or any PDF reader. Anno-REP then converts annotations in the document to open web annotations, as used by ATI. Authors can edit those and link them to data deposited with QDR. The ATI annotations can then be added to any copy of the manuscript or article available online.

As part of our activities, we closely worked with a group of researchers who used qualitative evidence to study a wide range of aspects in sociolegal research. In addition to articles annotated with ATI using the Anno-REP tool, they also completed a log of their process as well as a review of another researcher’s annotated manuscript. The resulting outputs and their discussion at a workshop broadened our understanding of what ‘research transparency’ for qualitative research entails. Traditional conceptions on transparency described three elements: data sharing, analytic transparency (i.e., how data were analyzed to reach a conclusion), and production transparency (i.e., how data were collected). To this, qualitative sociolegal researchers add transparency about context, interpretation, concepts, and ethics. Rather than lagging in transparency, qualitative researchers are innovators pushing the boundaries of what research should be transparent about. We are currently summarizing these findings in a manuscript that we are writing collaboratively with many of the researchers who participated in the workshop.

Adoption of new approaches is as important as their development. As part of the grant, we edited a symposium with authors using ATI and co-authored an article summarizing how it can be (and already is) used for teaching qualitative methods. As qualitative research is frequently published in books, we collaborated with the editors of the edited volume Constitution Makers on Constitution Making (Cambridge University Press) to add ATI annotations to all empirical chapters of the book. Showcasing practical applications and applicability of ATI will help popularize it among scholars. We also worked with Cambridge University Press, a leading publisher of social science research, to improve their workflow for publishing articles with ATI. While any article can use ATI, collaboration with Cambridge has allowed us to streamline both the publication and the display of annotations. As one initial success of this work, the American Political Science Review now officially supports manuscripts with ATI. Finally, we worked with a large grant-funded project in the UK that made extensive use of ATI to annotate qualitative research, demonstrating the increasing reach and popularity of the approach.
